Background on the Architecture of the Mixture Density Network

Mixture Density Networks for uncontrolled Reaction Networks

The general architecture of the Mixture Density Network is based on [SAcalG22].

In the following, to simplify the notations, we will omit the writing of parameters \(\xi\) and assume that \(M = M_{\theta}\).

The Mixture Density Network takes as inputs:

  • The time \(t \in \mathbb{R}_+^*\).

  • The propensity parameters \(\theta \in (\mathbb{R}_+^*)^M\) for the chosen Chemical Reaction Network.

It returns as outputs:

  • The mixture weights \(w \in [0,1]^K\).

  • The count parameters \(r \in R_+^K\).

  • The success probabilities \(q \in [0,1]^K\).

These outputs can be used to define the mass function \(\hat{p}(.;t,\theta)\):

\[\hat{p}(x;t,\theta) = \sum_{k=1}^K w_k(t,\theta) p_{\text{NB}}\big(x;r_k(t,\theta), q_k(t,\theta)\big)\]

Where \(K\) is the number of components in the distribution mixture and \(p_{\text{NB}}\) is the probability mass function of a Negative Binomial distribution \(\mathcal{NB}(r,q)\), defined as follows:

\[\forall k \in \mathbb{N}, p_{\text{NB}}(k;r,q) = \binom{k+r-1}{r-1}(1-q)^kq^r\]

Mixture Density Networks for controlled Reaction Networks

In the general case, each control parameter value is an additional input to the Mixture Density Network.

The Mixture Density Network now takes as inputs:

  • The time \(t \in \mathbb{R}_+^*\).

  • The propensity parameters of the uncontrolled reactions \(\theta \in (\mathbb{R}_+^*)^{M_{\theta}}\).

  • The propensity parameters of the controlled reactions \((\xi_1^1, ..., \xi_1^{M_{\xi}}, \xi_2^1, ..., \xi_L^{M_{\xi}}) \in (\mathbb{R}_+^*)^{M_\xi \times L}\).

The outputs remain the same:

  • The mixture weights \(w \in [0,1]^K\).

  • The count parameters \(r \in R_+^K\).

  • The success probabilities \(q \in [0,1]^K\).

The rest of the architecture does not change and the Mixture Density Network should be able to fit with the time windows.
